author: John Kasimba Omolo
title: Africa's Cardano Resource
description: There aren't many resources available for the East and Central African Regions

assessments.note: It is not clear how building a local stake pool significantly expands Cardano in Africa. A local marketplace to trade mpesa for ADA would be useful, though why Catalyst should be funding a 20,000 float of ADA is not clear. Transfers take seconds, this could be bootstrapped and built up using liquidity on other exchanges.

The proposal addresses the challenge of the lack of resources in east Africa for the East African community to be aware of Cardano. A detailed description is needed. Still, the current stage of this proposal needs more developmental descriptions to elaborate on the project's overall core mission while providing more context to the general audience.

The proposal seems to be very beneficial both for the African continent and for the Catalyst community, meeting the objectives of the challenge. This is because it is intended to create a first SPO in Kenya, in addition to other activities such as promoting workshops, which will aim to educate young people about ADA. Also, promote donations that benefit the local community and promote education, for example. In this way, Africa will certainly gain a lot, and the Catalyst community will be taken, on several fronts, to a new location.

The proposal has a noble aim; however bulk of the fund is being assigned for tasks seemingly unrelated. Currently, MASAI pool has a stake of 1K ADA and to make the pool sustainable there is a requirement to attract a large number of small delegators. The proposal aim to initiate a advertisement campaign in Kenya to do this. However the idea of marketplace is not very clear.

The proposal offers several avenues to promote Cardano in Eastern and Central Africa, which meets the goals of the challenge. Integration with mPesa seems especially promising, but also very difficult. I would think it would take an organization like IOHK to achieve this, rather than a community effort.

There is a huge potential to grow Cardona in Africa, and this project addresses it in its implementation plan. This proposal needs details on the team, who will implement this proposal, and their relevant experience. How do you plan to overcome the challenges of running a stake pool? Will you be working with yourself, or do you have a team?

The difference in this part of the proposal is that it is made by an African, and we intend, with this challenge, to increase the number of sites involved in Catalyst projects. According to what has been said, the author is a teacher, administrator and SPO operator. In other words, he has experience with the activity intended here, an experience that can be viewed better through the link that was attached. It is a site that speaks the newest SPO in question, has a means of contact and so on. Despite this, a more definite notion about the other team members could have been included in the proposal as well, because I believe that the SPO is not fully taught by the author, individually. It would then be interesting to know who the other people involved are, their areas of expertise and so on.

The proposer is operating a stake pool and has experience in DevOps. He claims no experience in marketing and product promotion being a teacher. It will be a major challenge for the proposer to achieve this with the requested fund.

I think the stake pool and the content production are realistic and productive. The integration with Atala Prism and mPesa seem less feasible to me at this time. I recommend a smaller proposal based on bulding the stake pool and providing content. If successful you would be at an advantage in future funding rounds.

More information should be given as to how each component addresses the challenge.  What does a local stake pool offer. providing donations to local school girls is nice, but why through the circuitous route of partial profits from a stake pool. Would the amount donated be significant?

In terms of the Roadmap, please provide some dates. For content: what content are you planning on creating? How many by when? How do you plan on delivering these content resources? Will it be in person or online?

The proposal details how the financial amount would be used. Also, we can know, in a detailed way, how the project would be going on, as the months go by. In this way, I think there is only a lack of a sense of what the objectives are to be achieved with each action step, but other than that, everything is well situated.

The progress of the project is subjective. There is no clarity on the marketplace and what is meant by ADA Float. The use of Atala for access to the website is also vague. There are limited measurable progress points in the proposal.

Funds are broken down into certain aspects of the project. But certain cost such as Atala Prism and the sanitation workshops seem hard to estimate at this time.  20k is requested for marketplace ADA float which seems unrealistic without relevant expertise and  a clear plan for the marketplace.

solution: Maasai.io will be the foremost resource tailored to E. & C. African regional needs through relevant and current content and an ADA market.
experience: John is Kenyan, a language teacher, a stake pool operator as well as a Linux/Kubernetes administrator.
